keyTakeAways: Erik and Lyle Menendez have been resentenced to 50 years to life for the 1989 murders of their parents, making them eligible for parole for the first time.
The resentencing decision was made by Judge Michael Jesic, who noted the brothers' rehabilitation and remorse, and acknowledged their efforts in prison programs.
The brothers have taken full responsibility for the killings, citing years of abuse by their father as justification, and have founded multiple prison programs to support rehabilitation.
Family members and supporters testified to the brothers' remorse, rehabilitation, and transformation, while prosecutors argue they have fabricated abuse claims and committed prison violations.
The Los Angeles County District Attorney Nathan Hochman opposes resentencing, citing fabricated self-defense claims and a moderate risk of violence.
The state parole board will evaluate the brothers’ eligibility, and Governor Gavin Newsom has the power to grant parole or commute their sentences immediately.
The brothers are also pursuing a habeas corpus petition to seek a new trial, citing new evidence about alleged abuse by their father.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Erik and Lyle Menendez, convicted in 1989 of murdering their parents in Beverly Hills, have been resentenced by Judge Michael Jesic to 50 years to life, making them eligible for parole for the first time. The decision follows extensive testimony from family members and prison staff highlighting the brothers’ remorse, rehabilitation, and participation in prison programs. While the brothers have taken full responsibility for the crimes and cited years of abuse by their father as justification, prosecutors and current District Attorney Nathan Hochman argue that their claims are fabricated and that they pose a moderate risk of violence. The state parole board is scheduled to hold a hearing on June 13, with Governor Gavin Newsom retaining the authority to ultimately grant or deny parole, or to commute their sentences immediately. The brothers are also pursuing a habeas petition to seek a new trial, citing new evidence of abuse by their father. This development raises broader questions about justice, rehabilitation, and the role of parole in capital punishment and high-profile criminal cases.
title: Erik and Lyle Menendez Resentenced to 50 Years to Life, Opening Door for Possible Parole, Judge Rules
